tabindex="0" href="/the-alters-ai-controversy#coral_thread"><div class="CommentCountSingle_content__Hwr8c"><svg viewBox="0 0 20 20" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M3.833 14.15v-.5H.5V.5h19v13.15H9.006l-.13.095-5.043 3.615v-3.21Z"></path></svg><span class="CommentCountSingle_count__c33Tp">23</span><span class="CommentCountSingle_countText__C3wK_">Comments</span></div></a></div></div></div><div class="single_contentContainer__2fe6_ Container_postContentWrapper__BPgvJ"><div class="single_postColumn__3AxVp"><div class="single_mobileSponsorshipWrapper__om_8r"></div><div class="PostContent_wrapper__oih1Z wp-embed-responsive"><div class="PostContent_content__FblEJ"><p>Some video games have been trying to use generative AI for years now,<a href="https://kotaku.com/hawken-reborn-impressions-steam-pc-505-games-mech-1850447998" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> and for the most part people simply have not been having it</a>. Why would we? It's lazy, it's ugly, it's an ethical black hole and it's being driven by an executive class desperate to lay off even more workers. While earlier and more brazen attempts at employing the tech were obvious, lately it's becoming more common for studios to slide a little AI-generated content in without drawing attention to it. </p><p><em>Jurassic World Evolution 3</em><a href="https://aftermath.site/jurassic-world-evolution-3-ai-removed" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> launched with some AI-generated character portraits, then got bullied into removing them</a>. <em>Clair Obscur</em>, which will be a lot of people's game of the year, appeared to<a href="https://x.com/nyanomancer/status/1917435885429150176" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> quietly launch with some AI-generated art then just as quietly patch it out</a>. I was <em>going </em>to review the city-building grand strategy game <em>Kaiserpunk</em> until I saw they were using AI-generated images for their dialogue sections, after which I promptly uninstalled it.</p><div><div><figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-bluesky-social wp-block-embed-bluesky-social"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper"><blockquote class="bluesky-embed" data-bluesky-uri="at://did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i/app.bsky.feed.post/3lstiwaoxcc2i" data-bluesky-cid="bafyreibwporrg2gr7pwwsjtznrsrhskfmxa5bzjrxpfvu5w26ki4eov33y"><p lang="en">We’ve seen a wide range of accusations regarding the use of AI-generated content in The Alters, and we feel it’s important to clarify our approach and give you more context.</p>— <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i?ref_src=embed">11 bit studios | WISHLIST DEATH HOWL (@11bitstudios.bsky.social)</a> <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i?ref_src=embed">2025-06-30T15:31:23.733Z</a></blockquote><script async src="https://embed.bsky.app/static/embed.js" charset="utf-8"></script></div></figure></div></div><p>The latest culprit is <em>The Alters</em>, which has found to have shipped not only with AI-generated placeholder text in-game, but also employed AI-generated translations in some of its side content as well. None of this was disclosed prior to the game's release; it was all discovered later, by players, and has prompted an <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">explanation </a>of sorts from the developers which <em>tries </em>to calm everyone down, but which has just made things worse, because if it took people discovering these specific instances to find that 11 Bit had used AI-generated content in the game's development, how do we know there's not more of it?</p><p>This is a HUGE BUMMER.<a href="https://aftermath.site/the-alters-impressions-review" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> I really liked this game</a>! And obviously didn't notice any of that on my playthrough, because I never stopped to read those screens and I played the game in English. To which I guess you could say, well, does it really matter if they slipped some AI stuff in there if I didn't notice it? Especially when, as developers 11 Bit <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">say</a>, it only constitutes "0.3%" of the overall text in the game?</p><p>Yes, it fucking does. I am not just against the employment of this tech for obvious, superficial reasons. All generative AI content is built on theft; surely writing some gibberish, or pasting some lorem ipsum, would have been preferable here? And <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">saying there were "time constraints"</a> involved in rushing AI-generated translations into the game is no excuse, either. Translators are highly skilled workers; using reputable ones costs a studio money, and takes time, but it avoids situations like <em>all</em> <em>this</em>, not to mention it’s just the right and professional thing to do.</p><div><div><figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-bluesky-social wp-block-embed-bluesky-social"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper"><blockquote class="bluesky-embed" data-bluesky-uri="at://did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru/app.bsky.feed.post/3lsu7uy27d22y" data-bluesky-cid="bafyreid2xsqo5iljj2xtw3gxw5qavzdlxbk4cjrrhaty5co7x3nye7ndr4"><p lang="ay">Stop using AI for placeholder assets. Use sketches. Use lorem ipsum. Use bright pink materials. Use programmer art for fucks sake, literally anything else. If your studio is using AI even for temp, even if they think they've covered their tracks, SPEAK UP because people WILL FIND IT</p>— <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru?ref_src=embed">Natalie Spitzel (@nat-the-dev.bsky.social)</a> <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru/post/3lsu7uy27d22y?ref_src=embed">2025-06-30T22:22:16.839Z</a></blockquote><script async src="https://embed.bsky.app/static/embed.js" charset="utf-8"></script></div></figure></div></div><p>Any studio making use of generative AI is sending a very clear message: they don't care about the cataclysmic effects AI is having on their own industry, they don't care that so much of AI content is slop, they don't care that millions of people out there who are their prospective fans and customers are <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/generative-ai-backlash/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">wholly opposed</a> to its use. I don't want to write about a game with AI in it, I don't want to support studios that use it and I don't want to spend a second of my time on it.</p><p>What's particularly grating about the situation with <em>The Alters</em>, aside from the fact it's absolutely coloured my enjoyment of what's an otherwise smart and interesting video game, is that the practice is becoming more common and harder to spot, and it’s increasingly just wearing us down.<a href="https://newsocialist.org.uk/transmissions/ai-the-new-aesthetics-of-fascism/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> Much like the nascent fascism that it has quickly grown to be the representative aesthetic of</a>, it feels like the hope with generative AI is that no matter how much you may hate it, the goal is to bombard you with its horrors and its excesses so frequently that you become numb to it. The more you see of it, the more you'll accept it as normal and the more you'll grow to if not enjoy then at least tolerate it, no matter how reluctantly.</p><p>Where you used to be able to spot generative AI a mile off, we're now needing days and even weeks after release for its use to become known. In some cases you can't even<a href="https://store.steampowered.com/news/group/4145017/view/3862463747997849618" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> rely on Steam's AI disclaimers</a>, because neither <em>Clair Obscur</em> or <em>The Alters</em> used them. It's getting to the stage where I just can't trust video games, and it means I'm starting to approach every game I play dubiously, every piece of key art and character portrait guilty until proven innocent, clouds hanging over every image and line of dialogue.</p><p>This isn't wearing down my opposition to AI-generated content, but it <em>is</em> wearing me down when it comes to approaching and enjoying video games. It is deeply unhealthy to bring so much scepticism into every new game I play, but if I'm going to take a principled stand here, what choice do I have? I do not want this shit in my games, <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/generative-ai-backlash/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">you don't want it either</a>, and I don't want to play or talk about games that contain it as a result. Yet I just did, and after really liking the game too, and so here I am writing <em>this</em>. This is getting <em>exhausting</em>.</p><p>I'd like every individual and team responsible for sneaking AI content in their games to know that whatever time or money you think you're saving, and however harmless and peripheral you think it's being implemented, you're doing immeasurable damage, because not only are people going to ultimately turn on your game, but you're playing your part in them wearing out on <em>all </em>games.</p></div></div></div><div class="single_postColumnSidebar__ZZuJF"></div></div><div class="single_metaFooterHasCTA__62X2C single_metaFooter__LK1_A Container_contentWidthWrapper__RL4A5"><div class="single_inner__pWuJ8"><div class="single_socialSharingCTA__eqU5q"><p>Enjoyed this article? <strong>Consider sharing it! </strong>New visitors get a few free articles before hitting the paywall, and your shares help more people discover Aftermath.</p>

To Trust That A Video Game Doesn’t Have AI Crap In It","contentBlocks":{"__typename":"ContentBlocks","isGutenberg":true,"blocks":[{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eSome video games have been trying to use generative AI for years now,\u003ca href=\"https://kotaku.com/hawken-reborn-impressions-steam-pc-505-games-mech-1850447998\"\u003e and for the most part people simply have not been having it\u003c/a\u003e. Why would we? It's lazy, it's ugly, it's an ethical black hole and it's being driven by an executive class desperate to lay off even more workers. While earlier and more brazen attempts at employing the tech were obvious, lately it's becoming more common for studios to slide a little AI-generated content in without drawing attention to it.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eJurassic World Evolution 3\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://aftermath.site/jurassic-world-evolution-3-ai-removed\"\u003e launched with some AI-generated character portraits, then got bullied into removing them\u003c/a\u003e. \u003cem\u003eClair Obscur\u003c/em\u003e, which will be a lot of people's game of the year, appeared to\u003ca href=\"https://x.com/nyanomancer/status/1917435885429150176\"\u003e quietly launch with some AI-generated art then just as quietly patch it out\u003c/a\u003e. I was \u003cem\u003egoing \u003c/em\u003eto review the city-building grand strategy game \u003cem\u003eKaiserpunk\u003c/em\u003e until I saw they were using AI-generated images for their dialogue sections, after which I promptly uninstalled it.\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"url","value":"https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i"},{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"type","value":"rich"},{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"providerNameSlug","value":"bluesky-social"}],"innerHTML":"\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-bluesky-social wp-block-embed-bluesky-social\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\"\u003e\u003cblockquote class=\"bluesky-embed\" data-bluesky-uri=\"at://did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i/app.bsky.feed.post/3lstiwaoxcc2i\" data-bluesky-cid=\"bafyreibwporrg2gr7pwwsjtznrsrhskfmxa5bzjrxpfvu5w26ki4eov33y\"\u003e\u003cp lang=\"en\"\u003eWe’ve seen a wide range of accusations regarding the use of AI-generated content in The Alters, and we feel it’s important to clarify our approach and give you more context.\u003c/p\u003e\u0026mdash; \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i?ref_src=embed\"\u003e11 bit studios | WISHLIST DEATH HOWL (@11bitstudios.bsky.social)\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:a564tr4carmvmz72gc2xog5i/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i?ref_src=embed\"\u003e2025-06-30T15:31:23.733Z\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cscript async src=\"https://embed.bsky.app/static/embed.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e","name":"core/embed","tagName":"figure","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eThe latest culprit is \u003cem\u003eThe Alters\u003c/em\u003e, which has found to have shipped not only with AI-generated placeholder text in-game, but also employed AI-generated translations in some of its side content as well. None of this was disclosed prior to the game's release; it was all discovered later, by players, and has prompted an \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i\"\u003eexplanation \u003c/a\u003eof sorts from the developers which \u003cem\u003etries \u003c/em\u003eto calm everyone down, but which has just made things worse, because if it took people discovering these specific instances to find that 11 Bit had used AI-generated content in the game's development, how do we know there's not more of it?\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eThis is a HUGE BUMMER.\u003ca href=\"https://aftermath.site/the-alters-impressions-review\"\u003e I really liked this game\u003c/a\u003e! And obviously didn't notice any of that on my playthrough, because I never stopped to read those screens and I played the game in English. To which I guess you could say, well, does it really matter if they slipped some AI stuff in there if I didn't notice it? Especially when, as developers 11 Bit \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i\"\u003esay\u003c/a\u003e, it only constitutes \"0.3%\" of the overall text in the game?\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eYes, it fucking does. I am not just against the employment of this tech for obvious, superficial reasons. All generative AI content is built on theft; surely writing some gibberish, or pasting some lorem ipsum, would have been preferable here? And \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/11bitstudios.bsky.social/post/3lstiwaoxcc2i\"\u003esaying there were \"time constraints\"\u003c/a\u003e involved in rushing AI-generated translations into the game is no excuse, either. Translators are highly skilled workers; using reputable ones costs a studio money, and takes time, but it avoids situations like \u003cem\u003eall\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003ethis\u003c/em\u003e, not to mention it’s just the right and professional thing to do.\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"url","value":"https://bsky.app/profile/nat-the-dev.bsky.social/post/3lsu7uy27d22y"},{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"type","value":"rich"},{"__typename":"ContentBlockAttribute","name":"providerNameSlug","value":"bluesky-social"}],"innerHTML":"\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-bluesky-social wp-block-embed-bluesky-social\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\"\u003e\u003cblockquote class=\"bluesky-embed\" data-bluesky-uri=\"at://did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru/app.bsky.feed.post/3lsu7uy27d22y\" data-bluesky-cid=\"bafyreid2xsqo5iljj2xtw3gxw5qavzdlxbk4cjrrhaty5co7x3nye7ndr4\"\u003e\u003cp lang=\"ay\"\u003eStop using AI for placeholder assets. Use sketches. Use lorem ipsum. Use bright pink materials. Use programmer art for fucks sake, literally anything else. If your studio is using AI even for temp, even if they think they\u0026#39;ve covered their tracks, SPEAK UP because people WILL FIND IT\u003c/p\u003e\u0026mdash; \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru?ref_src=embed\"\u003eNatalie Spitzel (@nat-the-dev.bsky.social)\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:dgd3hll42hpbg4nbroqnl5ru/post/3lsu7uy27d22y?ref_src=embed\"\u003e2025-06-30T22:22:16.839Z\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cscript async src=\"https://embed.bsky.app/static/embed.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e","name":"core/embed","tagName":"figure","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eAny studio making use of generative AI is sending a very clear message: they don't care about the cataclysmic effects AI is having on their own industry, they don't care that so much of AI content is slop, they don't care that millions of people out there who are their prospective fans and customers are \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/generative-ai-backlash/\"\u003ewholly opposed\u003c/a\u003e to its use. I don't want to write about a game with AI in it, I don't want to support studios that use it and I don't want to spend a second of my time on it.\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eWhat's particularly grating about the situation with \u003cem\u003eThe Alters\u003c/em\u003e, aside from the fact it's absolutely coloured my enjoyment of what's an otherwise smart and interesting video game, is that the practice is becoming more common and harder to spot, and it’s increasingly just wearing us down.\u003ca href=\"https://newsocialist.org.uk/transmissions/ai-the-new-aesthetics-of-fascism/\"\u003e Much like the nascent fascism that it has quickly grown to be the representative aesthetic of\u003c/a\u003e, it feels like the hope with generative AI is that no matter how much you may hate it, the goal is to bombard you with its horrors and its excesses so frequently that you become numb to it. The more you see of it, the more you'll accept it as normal and the more you'll grow to if not enjoy then at least tolerate it, no matter how reluctantly.\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eWhere you used to be able to spot generative AI a mile off, we're now needing days and even weeks after release for its use to become known. In some cases you can't even\u003ca href=\"https://store.steampowered.com/news/group/4145017/view/3862463747997849618\"\u003e rely on Steam's AI disclaimers\u003c/a\u003e, because neither \u003cem\u003eClair Obscur\u003c/em\u003e or \u003cem\u003eThe Alters\u003c/em\u003e used them. It's getting to the stage where I just can't trust video games, and it means I'm starting to approach every game I play dubiously, every piece of key art and character portrait guilty until proven innocent, clouds hanging over every image and line of dialogue.\u003c/p\u003e","name":"core/paragraph","tagName":"p","posts":null},{"__typename":"ContentBlock","innerBlocks":[],"attributes":[],"innerHTML":"\u003cp\u003eThis isn't wearing down my opposition to AI-generated content, but it \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e wearing me down when it comes to approaching and enjoying video games. It is deeply unhealthy to bring so much scepticism into every new game I play, but if I'm going to take a principled stand here, what choice do I have? I do not want this shit in my games, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/generative-ai-backlash/\"\u003eyou don't want it either\u003c/a\u003e, and I don't want to play or talk about games that contain it as a result. Yet I just did, and after really liking the game too, and so here I am writing \u003cem\u003ethis\u003c/em\u003e. readabilityObject.title: I'm Getting Real Tired Of Not Being Able To Trust That A Video Game Doesn't Have AI Crap In It - Aftermath
readabilityObject.content:
Some video games have been trying to use generative AI for years now, and for the most part people simply have not been having it. Why would we? It's lazy, it's ugly, it's an ethical black hole and it's being driven by an executive class desperate to lay off even more workers. While earlier and more brazen attempts at employing the tech were obvious, lately it's becoming more common for studios to slide a little AI-generated content in without drawing attention to it. 

Jurassic World Evolution 3 launched with some AI-generated character portraits, then got bullied into removing them. Clair Obscur, which will be a lot of people's game of the year, appeared to quietly launch with some AI-generated art then just as quietly patch it out. I was going to review the city-building grand strategy game Kaiserpunk until I saw they were using AI-generated images for their dialogue sections, after which I promptly uninstalled it.

The latest culprit is The Alters, which has found to have shipped not only with AI-generated placeholder text in-game, but also employed AI-generated translations in some of its side content as well. None of this was disclosed prior to the game's release; it was all discovered later, by players, and has prompted an explanation of sorts from the developers which tries to calm everyone down, but which has just made things worse, because if it took people discovering these specific instances to find that 11 Bit had used AI-generated content in the game's development, how do we know there's not more of it?

This is a HUGE BUMMER. I really liked this game! And obviously didn't notice any of that on my playthrough, because I never stopped to read those screens and I played the game in English. To which I guess you could say, well, does it really matter if they slipped some AI stuff in there if I didn't notice it? Especially when, as developers 11 Bit say, it only constitutes "0.3%" of the overall text in the game?

Yes, it fucking does. I am not just against the employment of this tech for obvious, superficial reasons. All generative AI content is built on theft; surely writing some gibberish, or pasting some lorem ipsum, would have been preferable here? And saying there were "time constraints" involved in rushing AI-generated translations into the game is no excuse, either. Translators are highly skilled workers; using reputable ones costs a studio money, and takes time, but it avoids situations like all this, not to mention it’s just the right and professional thing to do.

Any studio making use of generative AI is sending a very clear message: they don't care about the cataclysmic effects AI is having on their own industry, they don't care that so much of AI content is slop, they don't care that millions of people out there who are their prospective fans and customers are wholly opposed to its use. I don't want to write about a game with AI in it, I don't want to support studios that use it and I don't want to spend a second of my time on it.

What's particularly grating about the situation with The Alters, aside from the fact it's absolutely coloured my enjoyment of what's an otherwise smart and interesting video game, is that the practice is becoming more common and harder to spot, and it’s increasingly just wearing us down. Much like the nascent fascism that it has quickly grown to be the representative aesthetic of, it feels like the hope with generative AI is that no matter how much you may hate it, the goal is to bombard you with its horrors and its excesses so frequently that you become numb to it. The more you see of it, the more you'll accept it as normal and the more you'll grow to if not enjoy then at least tolerate it, no matter how reluctantly.

Where you used to be able to spot generative AI a mile off, we're now needing days and even weeks after release for its use to become known. In some cases you can't even rely on Steam's AI disclaimers, because neither Clair Obscur or The Alters used them. It's getting to the stage where I just can't trust video games, and it means I'm starting to approach every game I play dubiously, every piece of key art and character portrait guilty until proven innocent, clouds hanging over every image and line of dialogue.

This isn't wearing down my opposition to AI-generated content, but it is wearing me down when it comes to approaching and enjoying video games. It is deeply unhealthy to bring so much scepticism into every new game I play, but if I'm going to take a principled stand here, what choice do I have? I do not want this shit in my games, you don't want it either, and I don't want to play or talk about games that contain it as a result. Yet I just did, and after really liking the game too, and so here I am writing this. This is getting exhausting.

I'd like every individual and team responsible for sneaking AI content in their games to know that whatever time or money you think you're saving, and however harmless and peripheral you think it's being implemented, you're doing immeasurable damage, because not only are people going to ultimately turn on your game, but you're playing your part in them wearing out on all games.

readabilityObject.textContent: Some video games have been trying to use generative AI for years now, and for the most part people simply have not been having it. Why would we? It's lazy, it's ugly, it's an ethical black hole and it's being driven by an executive class desperate to lay off even more workers. While earlier and more brazen attempts at employing the tech were obvious, lately it's becoming more common for studios to slide a little AI-generated content in without drawing attention to it. Jurassic World Evolution 3 launched with some AI-generated character portraits, then got bullied into removing them. Clair Obscur, which will be a lot of people's game of the year, appeared to quietly launch with some AI-generated art then just as quietly patch it out. I was going to review the city-building grand strategy game Kaiserpunk until I saw they were using AI-generated images for their dialogue sections, after which I promptly uninstalled it.The latest culprit is The Alters, which has found to have shipped not only with AI-generated placeholder text in-game, but also employed AI-generated translations in some of its side content as well. None of this was disclosed prior to the game's release; it was all discovered later, by players, and has prompted an explanation of sorts from the developers which tries to calm everyone down, but which has just made things worse, because if it took people discovering these specific instances to find that 11 Bit had used AI-generated content in the game's development, how do we know there's not more of it?This is a HUGE BUMMER. I really liked this game! And obviously didn't notice any of that on my playthrough, because I never stopped to read those screens and I played the game in English. To which I guess you could say, well, does it really matter if they slipped some AI stuff in there if I didn't notice it? Especially when, as developers 11 Bit say, it only constitutes "0.3%" of the overall text in the game?Yes, it fucking does. I am not just against the employment of this tech for obvious, superficial reasons. All generative AI content is built on theft; surely writing some gibberish, or pasting some lorem ipsum, would have been preferable here? And saying there were "time constraints" involved in rushing AI-generated translations into the game is no excuse, either. Translators are highly skilled workers; using reputable ones costs a studio money, and takes time, but it avoids situations like all this, not to mention it’s just the right and professional thing to do.Any studio making use of generative AI is sending a very clear message: they don't care about the cataclysmic effects AI is having on their own industry, they don't care that so much of AI content is slop, they don't care that millions of people out there who are their prospective fans and customers are wholly opposed to its use. I don't want to write about a game with AI in it, I don't want to support studios that use it and I don't want to spend a second of my time on it.What's particularly grating about the situation with The Alters, aside from the fact it's absolutely coloured my enjoyment of what's an otherwise smart and interesting video game, is that the practice is becoming more common and harder to spot, and it’s increasingly just wearing us down. Much like the nascent fascism that it has quickly grown to be the representative aesthetic of, it feels like the hope with generative AI is that no matter how much you may hate it, the goal is to bombard you with its horrors and its excesses so frequently that you become numb to it. The more you see of it, the more you'll accept it as normal and the more you'll grow to if not enjoy then at least tolerate it, no matter how reluctantly.Where you used to be able to spot generative AI a mile off, we're now needing days and even weeks after release for its use to become known. In some cases you can't even rely on Steam's AI disclaimers, because neither Clair Obscur or The Alters used them. It's getting to the stage where I just can't trust video games, and it means I'm starting to approach every game I play dubiously, every piece of key art and character portrait guilty until proven innocent, clouds hanging over every image and line of dialogue.This isn't wearing down my opposition to AI-generated content, but it is wearing me down when it comes to approaching and enjoying video games. It is deeply unhealthy to bring so much scepticism into every new game I play, but if I'm going to take a principled stand here, what choice do I have? I do not want this shit in my games, you don't want it either, and I don't want to play or talk about games that contain it as a result. Yet I just did, and after really liking the game too, and so here I am writing this. This is getting exhausting.I'd like every individual and team responsible for sneaking AI content in their games to know that whatever time or money you think you're saving, and however harmless and peripheral you think it's being implemented, you're doing immeasurable damage, because not only are people going to ultimately turn on your game, but you're playing your part in them wearing out on all games.Stay in touchSign up for our free newsletterMore from AftermathI’m Mad We Didn’t Get A Spice Girls AnimeLook I'm not saying it would have been good, but just look at how cool it looks!Let’s All Read A Shitty Video Game Press Release Together'The development process will prioritize staying true to the distinctive tone and spirit of the original work, without...'Ozzy Osbourne Played A Video Game Convention In 2009, And It Ruled"The kids had a great time. That's the best part of my job: giving them the best time"See all posts
